key_insight: Integrating network (connectivity) information into self-supervised representation learning produces rich, transferable phenotypic embeddings of neuronal activity, enabling high‑throughput screens to find genetic modifiers of dynamic activity patterns.
problem_solved: Conventional phenotypic screening of neuronal activity is limited by high-dimensional, noisy temporal data and scarce labels; this work addresses the need for scalable, label‑efficient methods to detect subtle genetic effects on activity dynamics across interventions.
method: Network-aware self-supervised encoder that integrates local network/connection structure with temporal activity signals to learn robust, low‑dimensional phenotypic embeddings without labels.

Contrastive or predictive SSL objectives applied to activity segments to preserve dynamic motifs and network context, plus downstream clustering/classification to identify genetic perturbation phenotypes.
Scalable screening pipeline that applies learned embeddings across diverse neural interventions to rank and validate candidate genetic modifiers.
impact: Provides AI/ML practitioners a practical blueprint for combining graph/network information with self‑supervised representation learning on temporal biological data, improving sensitivity and scalability of high‑content phenotypic screens and enabling transfer across experiments.

paper_title: Network-aware self-supervised learning enables high-content phenotypic screening for genetic modifiers of neuronal activity dynamics
paper_authors: Parker Grosjean, Kaivalya Shevade, Cuong Nguyen, Sarah Ancheta, Karl Mader
